quest_title: The polynomial \( x^5 - 4x^4 + x^3 -2 \) has:
explanation_txt:
Let \( f(x) = x^5 - 4x^4 + x^3 -2 \)

So, \( f'(x) = 5x^{4} - 16 x ^{3} + 3x^{2} = 0 \)

Or, \( x^{2} ( 5x^2 - 16x + 3 ) = 0 \)

Or, \( x ^2 (x-3)(5x+1) = 0 \)

So, there are three extrema at \(0,3\) and \(1/5\)

Computing the second derivative;

\( f''(x) = 20x^3-48x^2+6x \) which gives \( f''(0) = 0, f(3) = 126, f(1/5) = -0.56 \)

So, the function has minima at \(x=3\) and maxima at \(x = 1/5\). The point \(x=0\) is inflection point, neither maxima nor minima.

So,

Or,

Computing the second derivative;

which gives

So, the function has minima at and maxima at . The point is inflection point, neither maxima nor minima.

ans2_plain_text: a local maxima at

quest_title:
\(P , Q\) and \(R\) are three coplanar forces acting at a point and
are in equilibrium. Given \(P = 1.9318 \mathrm { kg }\) wt, \(\sin \theta _ { 1 } = 0.9659\) the value of R is (in kg wt)
explanation_txt:
From Lami's Theorem,

\(\begin{array} { l } { \cfrac { P } { \sin \theta _ { 1 } } = \cfrac { Q } { \sin \theta _ { 2 } } = \cfrac { R } { \sin 150 ^ { \circ } } } \\ { \Rightarrow \cfrac { 1.93 } { \sin \theta _ { 1 } } = \cfrac { R } { \sin 150 ^ { \circ } } } \end{array}\)

\(\Rightarrow R = \cfrac { 1.93 \times \sin 150 ^ { \circ } } { \sin \theta _ { 1 } } = \cfrac { 1.93 \times 0.5 } { 0.9659 } = 1\)

and are three coplanar forces acting at a point and
are in equilibrium. Given wt, the value of R is (in kg wt)

quest_title: A person with his hands in his pockets is skating on ice at the velocity of 10 m/s and describes a circle of radius 50 m. What is his inclination with vertical?
explanation_txt:
The inclination of person from vertical is given by,

\(\tan \theta = \cfrac { v ^ { 2 } } { r g } = \cfrac { ( 10 ) ^ { 2 } } { 50 \times 10 } = \cfrac { 1 } { 5 }\)

\(\therefore \theta = \tan ^ { - 1 } ( 1 / 5 )\)

quest_title: A uniform chain of length \(\text{L}\) and mass \(\text{M}\) lying on a smooth table and one third of its length is hanging vertically down over the edge of the table. The work done to pull the hanging part on the table is
explanation_txt:
Mass per unit length \(=\cfrac{M}{\mathrm{L}}\)
Mass of hanging part \(=\cfrac{M}{L} \times \cfrac{L}{3}=\cfrac{M}{3}\)

Position of \(C G=\cfrac{L}{6}\)
Work done \((W)=\cfrac{M}{3} g \times \cfrac{L}{6}=\cfrac{M g L}{18}\)

quest_title: A cube of side 2.8cm and mass 33.3g floats in a bath of liquid. On increasing temperature, it just begin to sink at 40\({}^{0}\)c. The density of liquid at 0\({}^{0}\)c is 1.54g/cc then absolute expansivity of liquid, if expansivity of cube is negligible
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{array}{l}{\rho_{\mathrm{b}}=\cfrac{\mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{V}}=\cfrac{\mathrm{m}}{l^{3}}=\cfrac{33.3}{2.8^{3}}=1.516 \mathrm{g} / \mathrm{cc}} \\ {\rho_{\mathrm{b}}=\rho_{\mathrm{b}}^{40}}\end{array}\)

\(\text { or, } 1.516=\cfrac{\rho_{l}^{o}}{1+\gamma_{l} \times 40}\)

\(\begin{array}{l}{\text { or, } 1+\gamma_{l} \times 40=\cfrac{1.54}{1.516}} \\ {\text { or, } \gamma_{1}=\left(\cfrac{1.54}{1.516}-1\right) \cfrac{1}{40}=3.95 \times 10^{-4 / \mathrm{C}} \mathrm{C}}\end{array}\)
question_plain_title: A cube of side 2.8cm and mass 33.3g floats in a bath of liquid. On increasing temperature, it just begin to sink at 40c. The density of liquid at 0c is 1.54g/cc then absolute expansivity of liquid, if expansivity of cube is negligible
ans1_plain_text: 1.910/c
ans2_plain_text: 3.810/c
ans3_plain_text: 5.710/c
ans4_plain_text: 6.810/c

quest_title: The frequency of a sonometer wire is 100Hz. If the length of the string is doubled and the tension is changed, the new frequency becomes 75Hz. The ratio of original and final tension is
explanation_txt:
The frequency of sonometer wire is Given by; \(\mathrm{f}=\cfrac{n}{2 l} \sqrt{\cfrac{T}{\mu}}\)

i.e. \(\mathrm{f} \propto \cfrac{\sqrt{T}}{l}\)
\(\cfrac{f_{1}}{f_{2}}=\cfrac{l_{2}}{l_{1}} \times \sqrt{\cfrac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}} \\ {\Rightarrow \cfrac{100}{75}=\cfrac{2 l}{l} \times \sqrt{\cfrac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}}} \\ {\sqrt{\cfrac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}}=2 / 3 \Rightarrow \cfrac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}=4 / 9} \\ {\therefore \mathrm{T}_{1} : \mathrm{T}_{2}=4 : 9}\)

quest_title: In a certain charge distribution, all points having zero potential can be joined by a circle S. Points inside S have positive potential and points outside S have negative potential. A positive charge, which is free to move, is placed inside S
ans2_txt: It can move inside S, but it cannot cross S
ans4_txt: It may move, but will ultimately return to its starting point
explanation_txt: A free positive charge moves from higher (positive) potential to lower (negative) potential. Hence, it must cross S at some time.
question_plain_title: In a certain charge distribution, all points having zero potential can be joined by a circle S. Points inside S have positive potential and points outside S have negative potential. A positive charge, which is free to move, is placed inside S
explanation_plain_text: A free positive charge moves from higher (positive) potential to lower (negative) potential. Hence, it must cross S at some time.
ans2_plain_text: It can move inside S, but it cannot cross S
ans4_plain_text: It may move, but will ultimately return to its starting point

quest_title: \(\text{n}\)-equal capacitors are first connected in series and then in parallel. The ratio of maximum to minimum capacitance is
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{1}{C_{S}}=\cfrac{1}{C}+\cfrac{1}{C}+\ldots \ldots \ldots .\) n times

\(\therefore \quad C_{S}=\cfrac{C}{n}\)

Similarly,

\(C_{p}=C+C+\ldots \ldots \ldots \) n times

\(\therefore \quad C_{p}=n C\)

The ratio of maximum to minimum capacitance is given as:

\(\cfrac{C_{p}}{C_{S}}=\cfrac{n C}{\cfrac{C}{n}}=n^{2}\)

emerge out the field so, \(y < 0\).

quest_title: The coercivity of a bar magnet is 120 A/m. It is to be demagnetized by placing it inside a solenoid of length 120 cm and the number of turns 72. The current flowing through the solenoid is
explanation_txt:
Coercivity, \(H=n i\)
where \(n=\) no. of turn per unit length
\[
n=\cfrac{72}{120} \times 100=60 \text { and } H=120 \mathrm{A} / \mathrm{m}
\]
\(\therefore \quad i=\cfrac{H}{n}=\cfrac{120}{60}=2 \mathrm{A}\)

quest_title: Amongst \(L i C l , R b C l , B e C l _ { 2 } \text { and } M g C l _ { 2 } \), the compounds with the greatest and least ionic character respectively are
ans1_txt: \(L i C l \text { and } R b C l\)
ans2_txt: \(M g C l _ { 2 } \text { and } B e C l _ { 2 }\)
ans3_txt: \(R b C l \text { and } B e C l _ { 2 }\)
ans4_txt: \(R b C l \text { and } M g C l _ { 2 }\)
explanation_txt:
According to Fajan's rule RbCl has greatest ionic character due to large ionic size of Rb+ ion.

BeCl2 has least ionic character (Maximum covalent) due to small size of Be+2 ion .

\(log(x)\) is defined for positive numbers only. So, \(x > 0\).

So, the domain is \( {(0, \infty)} - {1} \)

quest_title: The \(p H\) of \(10 ^ { - 5 } M\) aqueous solution of \(N a O H\) is
explanation_txt:

quest_title: \[\lim _ { x \rightarrow 0 } \cfrac { 1 - \cos m x } { 1 - \cos n x } =\]
explanation_txt:
\[\begin{align} \lim _ { x \rightarrow 0 } \cfrac { 1 - \cos m x } { 1 - \cos n x } = & \lim _ { x \rightarrow 0 } \left\{ \cfrac { 2 \sin ^ { 2 } \cfrac { m x } { 2 } } { 2 \sin ^ { 2 } \cfrac { n x } { 2 } } \right\} \\ & = \lim _ { x \rightarrow 0 } \left[ \left\{ \cfrac { \sin \cfrac { m x } { 2 } } { \cfrac { n x } { 2 } } \right\} ^ { 2 } \quad \cfrac { m ^ { 2 } x ^ { 2 } } { 4 } \cdot \cfrac { 1 } { \left\{ \cfrac { \sin \cfrac { n \pi } { 2 } } { \cfrac { m \pi } { 2 } } \right\} ^ { 2 } } \cdot \cfrac { 4 } { n ^ { 2 } x ^ { 2 } } \right] \\ &= \cfrac { m ^ { 2 } } { n ^ { 2 } } \times 1 \\ &=\cfrac { m ^ { 2 } } { n ^ { 2 } } \end{align} \]

OR

Using L-Hopital Rule:

\[\lim _ { x \rightarrow 0 } \cfrac { 1 - \cos m x } { 1 - \cos n x } = \lim _ { x \rightarrow 0 } \cfrac { m \sin m x } { n \sin n x } = \lim _ { x \rightarrow 0 } \cfrac { m ^ { 2 } \cos m x } { n ^ { 2 } \cos n x } = \cfrac { m ^ { 2 } } { n ^ { 2 } }\]
explanation_plain_text:
OR

Using L-Hopital Rule:

quest_title: The area of loop between the curve y = asinx and x-axis is: [IOE - 062]

quest_title: The coordinate of moving particle at any time t are given by x = at\({}^{2}\) and y = bt\({}^{2}\) . The velocity of particle at time t is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array}{ll}{\mathrm{x}=\mathrm{at}^{2}} & {\mathrm{y}=\mathrm{bt}^{2}} \\ {\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{x}}=2 \mathrm{at}} & {\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{y}}=2 \mathrm{at}} \\ {\mathrm{V}=\sqrt{\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{x}}^{2}+\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{y}}^{2}}} & {=\sqrt{(2 \mathrm{at})^{2}+4 \mathrm{b}^{2} \mathrm{t}^{2}}} \\ {} & {=\sqrt{4 \mathrm{t}^{2}\left(\mathrm{a}^{2}+\mathrm{b}^{2}\right)}} \\ {} & {=2 \mathrm{t} \sqrt{\mathrm{a}^{2}+\mathrm{b}^{2}}}\end{array}\)

quest_title: Electrons accelerated by 5000V are allowed to fall on a metal surface of current 50\(\mu\)A. The force due to impact if electrons are brought to rest after impact is
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{aligned} \mathrm{eV}=& \cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2} \\ \text { or, } v &=\sqrt{\cfrac{2 \mathrm{eV}}{\mathrm{m}}}=\sqrt{2 \times 1.8 \times 10^{11} \times 5000} \\ &=4.24 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \text { and, } & \mathrm{I}=\cfrac{\mathrm{ne}}{\mathrm{t}} \end{aligned}\)
\(\begin{aligned} \text { or, } \cfrac{\mathrm{n}}{\mathrm{t}} &=\cfrac{\mathrm{I}}{\mathrm{e}}=\cfrac{50 \times 10^{-6}}{1.6 \times 10^{-19}}=3.125 \times 10^{14} \\ \therefore \mathrm{F} &=\cfrac{\mathrm{nmv}}{\mathrm{t}} \\ &=3.125 \times 10^{1} \times 9.1 \times 10^{-31} \times 4.24 \times 10^{7} \\ &=1.2 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}\)
question_plain_title: Electrons accelerated by 5000V are allowed to fall on a metal surface of current 50A. The force due to impact if electrons are brought to rest after impact is
ans1_plain_text: 1.2 10N
ans2_plain_text: 1.2 10N
ans3_plain_text: 1.2 10N
ans4_plain_text: 1.2 10N

quest_title: The cathode of a photoelectric cell is changed such that the work function changes from W1 to W2 (W2>W1). If the current before and after change are I1 and I2, all other conditions remaining unchanged, then (assuming hf > W2)
explanation_txt: The work function has no effect on current so long as \(h \nu > W _ { 0 }\). The photoelectric current is proportional to the intensity of light. Since there is no change in the intensity of light, therefore \(I _ { 1 } = I _ { 2 }\).

quest_title: A ray of light is incident on the surface of separation of a medium at an angle 45\(\mathrm{{}^\circ}\) and is refracted in the medium at an angle 30\(\mathrm{{}^\circ}\). What will be the velocity of light in the medium
explanation_txt: \(\mu =\cfrac{c}{v} =\cfrac{\sin i}{\sin r} =\cfrac{\sin 45^{o} }{\sin 30^{o} } \) \[\Rightarrow v=\cfrac{3\times 10^{8} }{\sqrt{2} } =2.12\times 10^{8} m/s\]

From Biot and Savart's law,

\(B=\cfrac{\mu _{0} }{4\pi } \cfrac{(2\pi -\theta )i}{R} =\cfrac{\mu _{0} }{4\pi } \cfrac{\left(2\pi -\cfrac{\pi }{2} \right)\times i}{R} \)\(=\cfrac{3\mu _{0} i}{8R} \)
